bibl.title: Letter from L.L. Williams, Jr., to Henry Rose Carter, January 25, 1922

div1.p: Williams believes that the malaria abstracts require Carter's comments to be useful. He has been filming locations that need draining as part of the anti-malaria campaign.

div1.head: Letter from L.L. Williams, Jr., to Henry Rose Carter, January 25, 1922
div1.opener:
ENNION G. WILLIAMS, M. D.
STATE HEALTH COMMISSIONER
ROY K. FLANNAGAN, M. D.
ASSISTANT COMMISSIONER
RICHARD MESSER,
CHIEF ENGINEER
M. E. BRYDON, M. D.
DIRECTOR CHILD WELFARE
Malaria
Abstract
Commonwealth of Virginia
STATE BOARD OF HEALTH
RICHMOND
January 25, 1922.
Dr. H. R. Carter,
2121 California St. N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
My dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
Escuse my delay in answering yours of the 14th
but it came while I was on leave of absence moving into my new
home at 3111 Stuart Avenue and immediately following I was com-
pelled to take a trip to Smithfield, Virginia.

Frankly, I think the present method of abstract-
ing malaria articles is advisable. I do not think that a sim-
ple abstract would do nearly as well as the abstract with comments.

I reason thus : I suspect that I am perhaps
what might be termed the average reader of these abstracts. I
figure that they are for my benefit. I must admit that without
your critical comments I would very frequently be unable to deter-
mine how much dependence could be placed on the accuracy and value
of the articles. Of course for Mr. LePrince and perhaps Mr.
Mayne these comments may at times be superfluous but for the average
reader they are essential.

In reading these articles I can easily see the
work you have put on them. From my point of view it is work well
worth while.

My mind is open and I will keep my eyes in simi-
lar condition anont the protective influence of stock against
malaria, also I think I can make some observations on the “humnhoming-
instinct” as you call it of A.quad., for in this work in rural
Virginia in at least two counties rather careful house-to-house
surveys have been started and would show prevalence or absence
of multiple cases of malaria to a home.

I helped Dr. Kane (State and I. H. B. man) in
putting across his antimalaria appropriation at Smithfield, Virginia,
in what to me was a distinctly unique method. I carried a movie
operative to the town and we took moving pictures of all the places
needing drainage and took care to show the Mayor and City Council
plus many of the leading citizens in the act of examining these spots.
-2-
A week later at a big mass meeting at night we showed them a movie
of their own town and the exact conditions needing correction.
It certainly went over with a whoop. When the work is done we will
set up the camera at the identical spots from which the first shots
were made and thus complete a “Before and After” picture. The only
drawback to doing this every time is that the picture costs $300.
However, it paid us in Smithfield because we wanted a “Before and
After” picture with a local significance for Virginia anyway and
chose Smithfield because this town was considered to be the hardest
mut to crack.

Mother is with me now and Dad I am expecting in
a day or two. After an absence of seven years I must say that
Mother seems hardly changed at all. Louis III races all over the
house on all fours and cuts capers and teeth with great regularity.
Gertrude joins me in love to you and Laura.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely, L. L. Williams, Jr.,
P. A. Surgeon. LLW:H
